title: Google's AI overview says 2026 is next year. Elon Musk reacts
snippet: Elon Musk noted the flaws in Google's AI Overview, which mistakenly claimed 2026 is next year.&nbsp;

title: Apple’s next iPhone set to enter ‘mass production’, key details leaked
snippet: Apple's iPhone 17e is reported to enter ‘Production’ post-CES. The cheapest iPhone may come with a 6.1-inch display, A19 processor, and an upgraded 18MP front camera.&nbsp;

title: Meta's Ray-Ban Display won’t launch in more countries just yet. Here’s why
snippet: Meta has paused the international rollout of its Ray Ban Display glasses due to limited inventory and unprecedented demand. The glasses were set to debut in UK, France, Italy, and Canada later in the year but the company is focusing on fulfilling its orders in the US.&nbsp;

title: YouTube Music recommendations are filling up with AI-generated tracks leaving netizens fuming
snippet: The rise of AI-generated music recommendations on YouTube has angered many users of the platform. Users have taken to Reddit and other platforms to voice their concerns.

title: Redmi Note 15 vs OnePlus Nord CE 5: Which is the best phone under  ₹25,000? Price, display, camera and more compared
snippet: With the launch of Redmi Note 15 5G, competition in the sub- ₹25,000 market has heated up against OnePlus Nord CE 5 5G. While both share display features, OnePlus excels in processing power and battery size, whereas Redmi offers a higher megapixel camera.

title: Realme 16 Pro+ vs OnePlus 15R: Which phone is a better choice under  ₹50,000? Price, specs and more compared
snippet: Realme 16 Pro+ launches in India at  ₹39,999, competing with OnePlus 15R. While OnePlus offers a more powerful processor and higher refresh rate display, Realme betters it with camera versatility. Both support 80W fast charging and come with IP68,IP69 and IP69k rating.

title: CES 2026: Nvidia confirms Rubin AI chips in production, eyes cloud rollout, China demand and autonomous vehicles
snippet: Nvidia says its next-generation Rubin data centre processors are now in production, with customer deployments planned for the second half of the year. CEO Jensen Huang unveiled performance gains, cloud adoption plans and new autonomous vehicle tools at CES.

title: Bright AMOLED smartwatches that bring sharper visuals to every fitness routine
snippet: AMOLED smartwatches offer sharper colours, better contrast and improved outdoor visibility, making daily health tracking, notifications and workouts easier to follow at a glance.

title: Elon Musk's xAI raises $20 billion in Nvidia-backed funding round
snippet: Elon Musk’s AI startup, xAI, said on Tuesday that it has raised $20 billion in fresh funding from participants including Nvidia, exceeding its original $15 billion target. title: Consumer founders’ deeptech play; VC fundraising swells in 2025
snippet: Happy Wednesday! With the deeptech wave rising in India, consumer tech founders are moving in. This and more in today's ETtech Morning Dispatch.

title: Voice AI firm Arrowhead raises $3 million in a round led by Stellaris Venture Partners
snippet: Arrowhead has raised $3 million in a funding round led by the early-stage venture capital firm Stellaris Venture Partners. The round also saw participation from angel investors such as Cred founder Kunal Shah and M2P founder Madhusudanan R, along with other senior fintech executives.

title: ETtech Explainer: Inside the 10-minute delivery model of quick commerce
snippet: The recent all-India gig worker strike highlighted whether the 10-minute quick commerce model is necessary, at the cost of riders risking their lives to deliver orders quickly. So, how is this 10-minute delivery system, which did not exist a few years ago, actually executed?

title: Veteran consumer internet founders roll up sleeves to launch  deeptech, AI startups
snippet: India is seeing a clear shift as founders and senior executives who built large consumer internet companies are now moving into deeptech and AI. After scaling marketplaces, apps and platforms, many are choosing harder, slower problems in robotics, aerospace, advanced manufacturing and AI research.

title: Healthtech funding drops on integrated care models' rise
snippet: According to Venture Intelligence, healthtech funding fell to $447 million last year from $707 million in 2024. Funding had peaked at $2.62 billion in 2021, before declining to $1.07 billion in 2022 and $682 million in 2023.

title: Signals for 2026: Spotting the shifts before they become headlines
snippet: For Indian startups, 2026 will be an inflection point where experiments of the years past create systems on which the future is built. There are patterns across data, founder behaviour, and market structure, elevated by the evolution of AI, that point to this.

title: VC fundraising rebounds fivefold to $3.3 billion in 2025

snippet: GCCs have been rapidly expanding into tier-II and tier-III cities, as ET reported earlier, with locations like Coimbatore, Jaipur, Indore, Vizag, and Kochi emerging as new hubs. snippet: Few people, if any, contemplate stars—celestial or cinematic—the way Aomawa Shields does.  An astronomer and astrobiologist, Shields explores the potential habitability of planets beyond our solar system. title: Secrets of the sleep-deprived brain
snippet: Nearly everyone has experienced it—after a night of poor sleep, your brain might seem foggy, and your mind drifts off when you should be paying attention. title: Under 10% of an earthquake’s energy makes the ground shake
snippet: Earthquakes are driven by energy stored up in rocks over millennia—energy that, once released, we perceive mainly in the form of the ground’s shaking. But a quake also generates a flash of heat and fractures and damages underground rocks. And exactly how much energy goes into each of these three pro

title: Listening to battery failure
snippet: Lithium-ion batteries produce faint sounds as they charge, discharge, and degrade. But until now, nobody could interpret those sounds to detect when a battery might be about to lose power, fail, or burst into flames. Now, MIT engineers have found a way to do that, even with noisy data. The findings

title: Building materials are getting closer to doubling as batteries
snippet: Concrete already builds our world, and an MIT-invented variant known as electron-­conducting carbon concrete (ec3, pronounced “e c cubed”) holds out the possibility of helping power it, too.
